column1: # By default "ra ya" means conjunct-ra (রেফ reph) followed by full য (ya)
# In words like "DRAM", ya-phalā + aa indicates the vowel /æ/. This is actually
# full ra (র) followed by ya-phalā plus aa. To block the default interpretation
# of "ra virama" as reph, the codepoint sequence is "ra joiner virama ya".
# In words like "rash" that start with /r/, the codepoint sequence should still
# be "ra joiner virama ya". Even though "ra" cannot be intended as reph at the
# beginning of a word, rendering algorithms in practice will render it as a
# reph in the absence of a joiner to block this interpretation.

column2: .d ee m oo k r ~y aa .t a
a ph a .t r ~y aa k a
g a bh a r^ n ~y aa n s a
a ~y aa .t a l aa s a
ee ~y aa p oo l oo
s a ph a .t a oo ;y ~y aa r a
a .n u b ii k .s a .n a

column1: # The following is a contrived example (not how "autoriksha" is normally
# spelled), show how the kṣ ligature can be blocked:

column2: a .t oo r i k non-joiner .s aa
b a ;m l aa d ee ;s a
i t i h aa s a
g a n .d aa r a
j a ;n g a l a
jh aa .r a kh a .n .d a
b i j ~n aa n a
p a d aa r^ th a
bh aa l u k a
b ~y aa k a r a .n a
;s a r^ k a r aa

column1: # Nukta, for additional letters in e.g. Pali

column2: p au t t a l i k a
j ~y oo t^ s n aa
p au t t a l i k a
p au t t a l i k a
m a ;y a m a n a s i ;m h a
m a ;y a m a n a s i ;m h a
w i k i p i .d i ;y aa
b ~y a w a h aa r a
